title: How did the ancient Egyptians make mummies? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Greek historian Herodotus, who lived in the fifth century BC, described the different methods The Most Costly Draw out the brain through the nostrilsTake out the whole contents of the belly, and clean the interior with palm-wine and spices.Fill the belly with pure myrrh, cassia and other spices and sew it together again.Cover up in natron for seventy days.Wash the corpse and roll it up in fine linen.Less Costly Fill the belly with oil of cedar-wood using a syringe by the breech, which is plugged to stop the drench from returning back; it dissolves the bowels and interior organs.After the appointed number of days with the natron treatment the cedar oil is let out and the corpse is left as skin and the bones.Returned the corpse the family.For the Poor Cleanse out the belly with a purge.Keep the body for seventy days of natron treatment.Return the corpse to the family. First, the internal organs were removed and preserved in canopic jars. Next, the body was packed in a mineral salt called Sodium Decahydrate (Natron) for up to three months. This dessicated the corpse, which prevents decomposition. Next, the body was washed with various perfumes and oils to remove the salt residue. After that, the body was carefully wrapped in linen bandages. In between layers of linen, the embalmer would hide various charms and amulets designed to ward off misfortune. Once the body was wrapped, funerary priests would recite the “Book of the Dead” over the corpse. The corpse was then placed in a series of coffins like a Russian nesting doll. Each coffin was more elaborate than the one before it. This entire process was very successful. Even today, there are mummies in such good condition that they can undergo medical scans.

Fascinating question. Let’s begin: Step One. Put a hook up the left nostril and remove the brain. Step Two. Fill the skull with a cleaning solution. Step Three. Using a flint knife, lay open the left flank and remove the liver, lungs, intestines and stomach. Step Four. Pack the cavity with bags of sawdust, natron (a desiccating salt) and spices and leave for 40 days. Step Five. Put the liver, lungs, intestines and stomach into a natron solution. Step Six. Place the desiccated organs into Canopic Jars in this order: liver- Imsety (Human), lungs- Hapi (Baboon), Stomach- Duamutef (Jackal) and Intestines- Qebehsenuef (Falcon) Step Seven. Wrap the body in linen strips soaked in resin. Step Seven. Bury the dead.

First,the body was taken to an ‘ibu’, or ‘place of purification’ – usually a tent close to the Nile. Here it would be ‘purified’ using water and palm oil, representing the deceased’s rebirth and helping to keep them smelling sweet for longer. Then the body was taken to the ‘pernefer’, another tent where the embalmment would take place. Only priests were qualified to carry out this procedure, with the chief embalmer known as the ‘hery seshta’. This man represented Anubis, the god of embalming and the dead, and often wore a jackal mask to show his importance. The hery seshta was responsible for wrapping the body and performing religious rites over the deceased – an element of the embalmment process just as vital as the physical preservation of the body.
